siteMetadata.title: Cooking In Pajamas
siteMetadata.description: Stories and Musings from Wayfaring Adventurers and Aspiring Home Cooks.

ghostPost.title: DAMN SON, Those are Some Seriously Loaded Fries
ghostPost.html:
For the few weeks, I've been bored at home while my parents are away at work. I've been taking some time off between graduation and when I start work next month. So when one of my friends was also bored at home during her spring break, she decided to come over and join me in being a bum for a day. And what better food to have while lazing around then some Mexican loaded fries.

Feel free to use sour cream instead of ranch or even add guacamole and other toppings you usually put on nachos! We didn't really want to leave the house and go grocery shopping, so we went with whatever was in the fridge. I usually make my own mexican seasoning, but feel free to replace the spices with a store bought seasoning if you want.

Mexican Loaded Fries

This is a very rough recipe. Feel free to throw in whatever you feel would taste best!

Ingredients:

  • ½ bag of fries (I used crinkle cut)
  • ranch (or sour cream)
  • as much shredded cheese as you want

    • Refried Beans

  • 1 can black beans
  • 1½ teaspoons cumin powder
  • 1 teaspoon paprika
  • salt to taste
  • cayenne pepper to taste
  • chili lime hot sauce to taste (optional)

    • Pico De Gallo Salsa

  • 3 roma tomatoes diced
  • ½ large onion diced
  • juice of ½ a lime
  • salt to taste
  • few sprigs of cilantro

    • Directions:

    Refried Beans: Pour the black beans onto a skillet on the stove. Add all of the spices and keep stirring until the beans are soft and are super flavorful.

    Salsa:Mix all the ingredients in a bowl and let it sit so that the salt and lime can bring out the flavor in the tomatoes.

    Bake the fries according to the directions on the packet. When the fries are done, don't turn off the oven. Top with the bean mixture and sprinkle all the cheese that your heart desires. Bake the topped fries in the oven until the cheese has melted. Take out the fries and top with salsa and ranch. Dig in!
ghostPost.plaintext:
For the few weeks, I've been bored at home while my parents are away at work.
I've been taking some time off between graduation and when I start work next
month. So when one of my friends was also bored at home during her spring break,
she decided to come over and join me in being a bum for a day. And what better
food to have while lazing around then some Mexican loaded fries.



Feel free to use sour cream instead of ranch or even add guacamole and other
toppings you usually put on nachos! We didn't really want to leave the house and
go grocery shopping, so we went with whatever was in the fridge. I usually make
my own mexican seasoning, but feel free to replace the spices with a store
bought seasoning if you want.



Mexican Loaded Fries
This is a very rough recipe. Feel free to throw in whatever you feel would taste
best!

Ingredients:
½ bag of fries (I used crinkle cut)
 ranch (or sour cream)
 as much shredded cheese as you wantRefried Beans
1 can black beans
 1½ teaspoons cumin powder
 1 teaspoon paprika
 salt to taste
 cayenne pepper to taste
 chili lime hot sauce to taste (optional)Pico De Gallo Salsa
3 roma tomatoes diced
 ½ large onion diced
 juice of ½ a lime
 salt to taste
 few sprigs of cilantro Directions:
Refried Beans:  Pour the black beans onto a skillet on the stove. Add all of the
spices and keep stirring until the beans are soft and are super flavorful.

Salsa:Mix all the ingredients in a bowl and let it sit so that the salt and lime
can bring out the flavor in the tomatoes.

Bake the fries according to the directions on the packet. When the fries are
done, don't turn off the oven. Top with the bean mixture and sprinkle all the
cheese that your heart desires. Bake the topped fries in the oven until the
cheese has melted. Take out the fries and top with salsa and ranch. Dig in!

previous.html:
Thanksgiving in our house is quite different that the traditional American Thanksgiving. First off, there's no turkey. Secondly, my mom makes a glorious display of Thanksgiving inspired Indian dishes! From masala dosa with cranberry chutney to stuffing upma (or bread upit) and spicy herb yams, we always enjoy a large variety of dishes. The only thing I personally demand every year is pumpkin pie! I love pumpkin pie. The wonderful blend of spices and sweet, and yet it's not that sweet; perfect for someone without a strong sweet tooth!

What do you get when you combine two of my favorite desserts in the world, pumpkin pie and tiramisu? Basically, it's one of the greatest desserts ever created by man. I was a little skeptical about how well this combination of flavors would be received by all of our thanksgiving guests, but it was a hit. Even without adding the usual brandy, rum, or amaretto, everyone loved the wonderful blend of flavors.

One warning I have about this recipe is that you should be careful in blending the cornstarch mixture into the pumpkin creme. If this step is not done properly, you will have cornstarch lumps in your tiramisu and that is just gross.

Pumpkin Tiramisu

Recipe modified from http://www.nytimes.com/projects/well/vegetarian-recipes/#recipe/pumpkin-tiramisu

Ingredients:

Pumpkin Creme

  • ⅓ cup cornstarch
  • ¼ cup water
  • ¾ cup milk
  • 1 (15-ounce) can pumpkin puree
  • ¾ cup maple syrup
  • ¾ teaspoon allspice
  • ¾ teaspoon cinnamon
  • ¾ teaspoon nutmeg
  • ½ teaspoon salt

    • Tiramisu

  • 1 pot black coffee
  • 1 package lady finger biscuits
  • 16oz mascarpone cheese
  • ground chocolate for garnishing

    • Directions:

    To make the Pumpkin Creme: In a small bowl, thoroughly mix cornstarch and water with a whisk or fork until there are NO LUMPS and set aside. In a medium saucepan, whisk together milk, pumpkin puree, maple syrup, spices and salt, and heat over medium heat until it just begins to boil, about 5 minutes. Slowly drizzle cornstarch mixture into the saucepan, whisking continuously. Cook until the mixture becomes very thick, about 5 minutes, whisking frequently. Pour the creme into a bowl and let cool about 15 minutes. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap so that the plastic wrap is touching the top of the creme. Refrigerate for a few hours or overnight.

    To assemble: Soak each lady finger biscuit in coffee for a few seconds and quickly place in a large dish. Spread a layer of Pumpkin Creme on top. Repeat this process for as many layers fill up the dish or all the components run out. Alternate spreading a layer of Pumpkin Creme and mascarpone cheese between layers of biscuit.
previous.title: The Love Child of Pumpkin Pie and Tiramisu

next.html:
Whenever I'm home, my mom sometimes sautés some vegetables and keeps them for me to use with whatever I make for lunch. Usually that ends up being some simple pasta, vegetable fajitas, or toppings on a veggie burger. This time, I figured, why not try something different and make a veggie patty using these vegetables!

It ended up being some kind of frittata/omelets/burger patty thing. While I may not be entirely sure what to call it, it tasted wonderful. And to my delight, it photographed really well! I actually ate the patty by itself but you could definitely eat these inside a burger or chopped up in a salad. So many options!

Quinoa Veggie Patty

Recipe inspired by http://www.halfbakedharvest.com/epic-crispy-quinoa-burgers-topped-sweet-potato-fries-beer-caramelized-onions-gruyere/

Ingredients:

  • 1 cup cooked red quinoa
  • 1 cup chopped mushroom
  • 1/2 cup sliced zucchini
  • 1/2 cup sliced squash
  • 1/4 cup sliced red onion
  • 1 egg
  • 1 handful baby spinach
  • 1 tsp red pepper flakes or dash of cayenne
  • salt and pepper to taste
  • lime slices for garnishing
  • chopped green onion for garnishing

    • Directions:

    Mix all ingredients together and roll into medium-sized balls. Flatten and grill the patties on a Panini press until fully cooked. I used a Panini press because I like the lines my burgers get, but feel free to use a skillet. Garnish with a few chopped green onions and enjoy with some Italian dressing!
next.title: I Quinoa Believe It's a Veggie Patty
